com.github.mmichaelis.hamcrest.nextdeed.concurrent

Interface WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - input the function will receive
    R - output the function will provide
    All Superinterfaces:
    Supplier<Function<T,R>>, WaitBuilder

    public interface WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R>
extends Supplier<Function<T,R>>, WaitBuilder

    A builder for WaitFunctions.

    Since:
    1.0.0

      • onTimeout

        @NotNull
WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R> onTimeout(@NotNull
                                             Function<WaitTimeoutEvent<T,R>,R> timeoutFunction)

        Function to apply to timeout event on timeout. The function might consider to throw an exception for example or ignore the actual timeout but return some default result instead.

        Parameters:
        timeoutFunction - function to call on timeout
        Returns:
        self-reference

      • withinMs

        @NotNull
WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R> withinMs(long timeoutMs)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder

        How much time it might take to fulfill predicate. Otherwise time out.

        Mind that the timeout is not hard regarding the system response time. If your timeout is 100 ms but the system takes 1000 ms to answer and assuming the state is reached, the call is still successful. In other words: This is not to guarantee certain time measures – but to give some grace to the system to reach the wanted state.

        Specified by:
        withinMs in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        timeoutMs - timeout in milliseconds; must be greater than or equal to 0
        Returns:
        self-reference

      • within

        @NotNull
WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R> within(long timeout,
                                          @NotNull
                                          TimeUnit timeUnit)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder

        How much time it might take to fulfill predicate. Otherwise time out.

        Mind that the timeout is not hard regarding the system response time. If your timeout is 100 ms but the system takes 1000 ms to answer and assuming the state is reached, the call is still successful. In other words: This is not to guarantee certain time measures – but to give some grace to the system to reach the wanted state.

        Specified by:
        within in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        timeout - timeout amount; must be greater than or equal to 0
        timeUnit - timeout time unit
        Returns:
        self-reference

      • withFinalGracePeriodMs

        @NotNull
WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R> withFinalGracePeriodMs(long gracePeriodMs)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder

        Configures the grace period to grant after the timeout is reached.

        Example:

        Your system responds within 100 ms and you start with an initial delay at 0 ms. Having a timeout of 140 ms the remaining sleep time after first failure is 40 ms. But giving a grace of 50 ms will cause the last sleep to take 90 ms thus giving the system more chances to reach the wanted state.

        Specified by:
        withFinalGracePeriodMs in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        gracePeriodMs - grace period in milliseconds; must be greater than or equal to 0
        Returns:
        self-reference

      • withFinalGracePeriod

        @NotNull
WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R> withFinalGracePeriod(long gracePeriod,
                                                        @NotNull
                                                        TimeUnit timeUnit)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder

        Configures the grace period to grant after the timeout is reached.

        Example:

        Your system responds within 100 ms and you start with an initial delay at 0 ms. Having a timeout of 140 ms the remaining sleep time after first failure is 40 ms. But giving a grace of 50 ms will cause the last sleep to take 90 ms thus giving the system more chances to reach the wanted state.

        Specified by:
        withFinalGracePeriod in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        gracePeriod - grace period; must be greater than or equal to 0
        timeUnit - time unit of grace period
        Returns:
        self-reference

      • withInitialDelayMs

        @NotNull
WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R> withInitialDelayMs(long initialDelayMs)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder

        The initial delay and also base delay for polling. The default initial delay is 0 milliseconds.

        Note:
        As the polling will never increase but only decrease the initial delay is also the minimum polling interval. It might be used, if you know that your system for example takes at least two seconds to recover from a request.
        Specified by:
        withInitialDelayMs in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        initialDelayMs - initial delay in milliseconds; must be greater than or equal to 0
        Returns:
        self-reference

      • withInitialDelay

        @NotNull
WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R> withInitialDelay(long initialDelay,
                                                    @NotNull
                                                    TimeUnit timeUnit)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder

        The initial delay and also base delay for polling. The default initial delay is 0 milliseconds.

        Note:
        As the polling will never increase but only decrease the initial delay is also the minimum polling interval. It might be used, if you know that your system for example takes at least two seconds to recover from a request.
        Specified by:
        withInitialDelay in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        initialDelay - initial delay; must be greater than or equal to 0
        timeUnit - time unit of initial delay
        Returns:
        self-reference

      • deceleratePollingBy

        @NotNull
WaitFunctionBuilder<T,R> deceleratePollingBy(double decelerationFactor)
        Description copied from interface: WaitBuilder
        Factor by which the polling interval is decelerated. Greater values will decelerate more, a value of 1 won't decelerate at all but keep the polling interval.
        Specified by:
        deceleratePollingBy in interface WaitBuilder
        Parameters:
        decelerationFactor - factor to decelerate; must be greater than or equal to 1
        Returns:
        self-reference
